posts.content:
Hey all! This idea came about when I was trying to create a new character for my RP server, which should automatically tell you he's not a powergame-type character--though by all means, not weak. This guy can do almost anything: open locks, disable traps, scout, heal, buff, cast, melee...he's very much a "jack of all trades, master of none", and will do well either in a party or on his own.

Thanks to Mick and Empyre for their help!

"A smirk curled around your lips as you turned out the contents of the safe into your bag. Really, it was too easy--pick out a mark, pose as a cleric of some goody-two-shoes deity, go to their door offering to bless their household, take note of the layout and loot once inside, and return at night to steal it all. Let fools and do-gooders rush toward poverty and death; you'd be more than happy to profit at their expense. A particularly beautiful sapphire caught your eye, and you set it aside to later be offered as tribute to the Lord of Shadows. Satisfied with your gain, you rose to your feet, hoisted your bags over your shoulders, and walked right past the guards, out into the night."

~~Demarch of Mask~~

Notes:

1) You are, first and foremost, a self-reliant support character. You can do almost anything...except tank. Your HPs are low-ish for a melee character, buffs only go so far, and being the center of attention means you aren't utilizing your 8d6 sneak attacks. Keep to the edges of the fray, where you can summon, buff, cast offensive spells, or dip in and out for melee at your pleasure.

2) If you'd like more power, you can swap out one level of Cleric and three of Rogue for Fighter 4, earning you three bonus feats and access to EWS. The cost is dispellable buffs, 1d6 less Sneak Attack. no Crippling Strike, and a 20% XP bonus. I didn't do it because this is an RP-build first and foremost, and Fighter doesn't really fit, but I still thought I should note the option.

3) Sneak-immune enemies are still your bane, but the Cleric's abilities make them easier to handle, especially undead. Your CHA isn't high enough to solidly rely on Turn Undead, but the buffs and divine spells help you out a lot.

4) Sanctuary and Greater Sanctuary are the ultimate scouting spells, as they lets you waltz into a place, take note of the enemies, disable all traps, pick all locks, and waltz back out.

5) Your weapon doesn't have to be shortswords; any finessable weapon will do. If you want kukris, though, you'll have to shuffle feats around and drop Knockdown for Exotic Weapon Proficiency.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Apocrypha wrote:
Alignment: Neutral Evil

 
Make it clear what the minimum requirements are for those seeking to try the build in another venue and then your personal bias.  In this build, there are no alignment restrictions.
02: Cleric(1): Domain Trickery, Domain Evil
 
I am assuming the Evil domain was chosen for RP reasons.  To optimize AC and AB, you'd chose either Animal or War.  On some servers that have implemented deity restrictions, the combination you have chosen may be prohibited as could any combination of the two I've mentioned.
15: Cleric(12): Improved Two-Weapon Fighting
18: Cleric(14): Blind Fight
 
ITWF's add'l -5 BAB OH attack is less signficant than being able to deal efficiently with concealed foes which are likely to begin appearing by level 15.  I'd swap these feats.
Bluff 35 (34), Disable Trap 21(25), Hide 42(50), Move Silently 42(50), Open Lock 1(9), Search 27(29), Spellcraft 43(45), Spot 42(46), Tumble 40(48), UMD 36(35)
 
I am assuming a non-combat skill like Bluff was chosen as a prereq for the RP concept.  But do you really need that many ranks?  If so, this toon will still need ranks in Set Trap to act as a fully-fledged rogue. 5 ranks is adequate to set all deadly traps except Gas.  I see 2 unneeded ranks in UMD that can be cannabalized (UMD 33 is plenty).  There's 3 to spare in Disable traps if you neglect recovering those lame DC Gas traps.  This skill set will spot Epic traps with slow recon but will be hard-pressed to disarm them without some serious skill boost items or Trickery.  There is always sacrificial summons to trigger them as long as they get spotted which they will with careful scouting.  Your choice.
1) You are, first and foremost, a self-reliant support character. You can do almost anything...except tank.
 
...not if you can't at least set traps.  Think ROGUE!  Protect your party!
4) Sanctuary and Greater Sanctuary are the ultimate scouting spells, as they lets you waltz into a place, take note of the enemies, disable all traps, pick all locks, and waltz back out.
 
GS: yes.  Sanctuary: no! It sux, actually.  "Waltzing" through mobs of weak-willled foes will have only one result... you will be spotted by the first one that rolls a 20 on the Will save and all the rest will join in.  And that's the irony of the weak... they ALWAYS roll lucky.  You can set your watch by it.  Stick with GS, Invis or pure stealth for recon and your toon should be good to go.
